Benign Nevus.description: A benign nevus (mole) is a cluster of melanocytes that appears as a small, well-defined pigmented spot on the skin. It is usually uniform in color and shape, and carries minimal risk of malignancy.

Malignant Melanoma.description: Malignant melanoma is a serious form of skin cancer originating from melanocytes. It often presents as a changing mole or dark patch with irregular borders, and can metastasize if not caught early.

Fungal.description: Fungal infections (e.g., tinea corporis, athlete’s foot) are caused by dermatophytes. They appear as itchy, red, ring-shaped lesions with central clearing.

treatments.name: Topical or oral antifungal agents (e.g., terbinafine)

Eczema.description: Eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition characterized by dry, itchy, and red patches, often triggered by allergens or irritants.

Benign Tumor.description: Benign skin tumors (e.g., lipomas, dermatofibromas) are non-cancerous growths that typically grow slowly and do not spread to other tissues.

Acneiform.description: Acneiform eruptions include acne vulgaris and related disorders, presenting with comedones, papules, pustules, and sometimes cysts on oily skin areas.

treatments.name: Topical retinoids and salicylic acid cleansers

Viral.description: Viral skin infections (e.g., herpes simplex, molluscum contagiosum) cause grouped vesicles or dome-shaped papules, often with a clear fluid.

Psoriasis.description: Psoriasis is an autoimmune disorder featuring well-demarcated, silvery scaly plaques on extensor surfaces. It often follows a chronic course with flares and remissions.

treatments.name: Topical vitamin D analogues or coal tar preparations

Malignant.description: This category encompasses various malignant skin lesions (other than melanoma) such as basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma, characterized by persistent non-healing lesions.

Autoimmune.description: Autoimmune skin diseases (e.g., lupus erythematosus, lichen planus) result from immune-mediated tissue damage, appearing as rashes, plaques, or mucosal lesions.

Alopecia.description: Alopecia disorders (e.g., alopecia areata) involve non-scarring hair loss in patches. They may be autoimmune in nature and can fluctuate over time.

Pigmentation.description: Pigmentation disorders (e.g., melasma, vitiligo) cause hypo- or hyperpigmented patches due to melanocyte dysfunction or loss.

treatments.name: Topical hydroquinone or narrowband UVB therapy

Pre Malignant Lesion.description: Pre-malignant skin lesions (e.g., actinic keratosis) are dysplastic changes that can progress to squamous cell carcinoma if untreated.

Vascular.description: Vascular lesions (e.g., hemangiomas, angiomas) are benign proliferations of blood vessels, often appearing red or purple on the skin.

Bacterial.description: Bacterial skin infections (e.g., impetigo, cellulitis) present with erythema, warmth, swelling, and sometimes pustules or honey-colored crusts.

Nail Disorder.description: Nail disorders (e.g., onycholysis, Beau’s lines) can result from trauma, infection, or systemic disease, altering nail color, thickness or contour.

treatments.name: Antifungal nail lacquer or corrective nail care

Other.description: This category includes miscellaneous skin conditions not fitting other groups, such as scars, calluses, or idiopathic rashes.

treatments.name: Refer to a dermatologist for personalized care

Benign Keratosis.description: Benign keratoses (e.g., seborrheic keratosis) are common, stuck-on-appearing waxy plaques that rarely progress to malignancy.
